J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> If a class implements interfaces A, B and C, then I would tend to want 
> Contract Tests for each interface. If we use TestCase subclassing to do 
> that in JUnit, then that would mean three test case classes:
> 
> 1. TestXAsA extends ATests
> 2. TestXAsB extends BTests
> 3. TestXAsC extends CTests
> 
> This might bother some people, but it doesn't bother me: I don't need 
> one test case class per production code class.

One test per class makes it easy to find tests that may be affected by a 
feature change. This makes it easy to run localised tests.

Having tests scattered all over the place means that you tend to need to 
run all tests to make sure that a change hasn't introduced a bug. If your 
tests take a long time to run, you won't be inclined to do this.

So... the need to keep test code in one class is proportional to the length 
of time it takes your tests to run. Hmmm - another reason to try to keep 
tests running fast. :)

(I use the TextXsomesuffix pattern as well... e.g. TestXDB for database 
dependent tests)
